This phenomenon is known as photic sneeze reflex or ACHOO (autosomal dominant compulsive helio-ophthalmic outbursts of sneezing) syndrome. It occurs in about 18-35% of the population and is triggered by exposure to bright light, such as sunlight. The exact mechanism behind this reflex is not fully understood, but it is believed to be due to a cross-wiring of signals between the optic nerve and the trigeminal nerve, which controls the sneeze reflex. Choices: (A) Take a couple of full heavy duty clothes hangers, then hook several hangers of clothes on Those hangers and carry them all at once. (B) Take a couple of empty heavy duty clothes hangers, then hook several hangers of clothes on Those hangers and carry them all at once.

Taking a couple of empty heavy duty clothes hangers and hooking several hangers of clothes on them is a more plausible answer as it reduces the weight of the load being carried. Carrying a couple of full heavy duty clothes hangers with clothes on them can be heavy and difficult to manage. By using empty hangers, the weight is significantly reduced, making it easier to carry multiple hangers of clothes at once.

Taking a couple of full heavy duty clothes hangers and hooking several hangers of clothes on them is a more plausible answer because it allows you to carry multiple items at once without having to take up too much space or make multiple trips. Additionally, the weight of the clothes on the hangers will help keep them in place and prevent them from sliding off during transport. Taking empty hangers would require more trips and may result in the clothes sliding off the hangers.
